candidateProvision.title: Total Small Business Set-Asides
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: This provision requires setting aside acquisitions between micro-purchase and simplified acquisition thresholds for small businesses. Since the $145,000 purchase exceeds micro-purchase threshold and market research shows capable small businesses, it must be set aside for small business competition unless exceptions apply.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Total Small Business Set-Asides
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: With an estimated value of $145,000, this procurement exceeds the micro-purchase threshold but is below the simplified acquisition threshold. Since market research indicates at least five capable small businesses, this procurement must be set aside exclusively for small businesses, especially given the agency's previous non-compliance with small business utilization requirements.

candidateProvision.title: Effect of Listing
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: This prohibits contracting with debarred or proposed for debarment contractors. Since two potential suppliers appear on proposed debarment list, they must be excluded from consideration unless agency head determines compelling reason exists to use them.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Effect of Listing
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: Two potential suppliers are proposed for debarment. This provision prohibits soliciting offers from or awarding contracts to debarred, suspended, or proposed for debarment contractors unless there's a compelling reason determined by the agency head. These suppliers must be excluded from consideration in the office equipment purchase.

candidateProvision.title: Sustainable Acquisition Policy
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: Requires 95% of new contracts to meet sustainability criteria. Since computers/printers must be ENERGY STAR certified, this provision mandates including these requirements in the solicitation and evaluating offers accordingly.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Sustainable Acquisition Policy
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: The agency's sustainability initiative aligns with this provision requiring federal agencies to advance sustainable acquisition. The computers and printers must be ENERGY STAR certified, meeting the requirement that products be energy-efficient. This provision mandates that 95% of new contract actions require products with specific environmental attributes.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: Lack of formal supplier qualification process and failure to check exclusion lists
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Implement documented supplier qualification procedures including verification of certifications/licenses and checking against government exclusion lists. Create standardized supplier evaluation forms and maintain records of qualification activities for each supplier.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: Undisclosed conflict of interest with Purchasing Manager's brother-in-law's company
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Immediately disclose the relationship, implement conflict of interest policy requiring annual disclosures, and recuse the Purchasing Manager from decisions involving this supplier. Consider competitive bidding for future orders.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: Inadequate documentation of purchase requirements and changes
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Implement document control procedures requiring written specifications, formal change orders for modifications, and retention of records for required period. Train staff on proper documentation practices and implement quality checks.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Do not proceed with this supplier until certification can be verified. Request current certification documents directly from the certifying body. If time is critical, identify alternative certified suppliers or consider delaying production until proper verification is complete.

keyScenario.correctAction: Do not proceed with this supplier until proper verification of certifications is completed. Request on-site audit or third-party certification verification. Implement a formal supplier qualification process that includes verification of all certifications through official databases. Consider alternative suppliers with verified certifications even if costs are higher to ensure regulatory compliance.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Require supplier to provide complete conflict minerals reporting template (CMRT) with detailed supply chain information. Conduct due diligence to verify conflict-free status before purchase. Implement conflict minerals policy and reporting procedures to ensure SEC compliance.

keyScenario.correctAction: Delay purchase until supplier provides detailed documentation of their supply chain. Request a Conflict Minerals Reporting Template (CMRT) from the supplier. Implement a conflict minerals due diligence program that includes supplier verification. Consider engaging a third-party auditor to verify supplier claims. Ensure compliance with SEC reporting requirements for conflict minerals.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Do not accept outdated SDS documents. Require supplier to provide current GHS-compliant SDS before purchase. Verify TSCA compliance status of all chemical components. Consider alternative suppliers with proper documentation if timely updates cannot be provided.

keyScenario.correctAction: Do not purchase materials with outdated SDS. Request current GHS-compliant SDS from the supplier. If supplier cannot provide updated documentation, seek alternative suppliers. Implement a procedure to verify SDS compliance before purchasing hazardous materials. Ensure all hazardous materials have current SDS documentation that meets GHS requirements.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Make good faith effort to meet small business subcontracting goals. Solicit bids from both the established large business and qualified small business. If small business can meet requirements at fair price, award to them. Document decision-making process for compliance reporting.

keyScenario.correctAction: Award the subcontract to the qualified small business to meet federal contract small business subcontracting goals. Develop a mentor-protégé relationship between your company and the small business to address experience concerns. Document the selection process and small business utilization in your subcontracting plan. Provide appropriate support to ensure successful performance by the small business.
